H0.text: An abundance of dissolved oxygen results from the decomposition of the algae blooms caused by farm fertilizers carried by runoff into the Mississippi River and down to the Gulf of Mexico.

H1.text: Dead zones where there are no fish result from the decomposition of algae blooms caused by farm fertilizers carried by runoff into the Mississippi River and down to the Gulf of Mexico.

H2.text: A reduction in atmospheric carbon dioxide results from the decomposition of the algae blooms caused by farm fertilizers carried by runoff into the Mississippi River and down to the Gulf of Mexico.

H3.text: Food webs with rapidly growing populations result from the decomposition of algae blooms that form when farm fertilizers are carried by runoff into the Mississippi River and down to the Gulf of Mexico.

A4.text: Natural decomposers present in the water begin decomposing the dead algae, consuming dissolved oxygen present in the water during the process.

A5.text: This can result in a sharp decrease in available dissolved oxygen for other aquatic life. Without sufficient dissolved oxygen in the water, animals and plants may die off in large numbers.
